t: Job 24
“Why*pn are not times of judgment kept by the Almighty, and*ld why do those who know him never see his days?
Some*ln move landmarks; they*ld seize flocks and pasture them.
They*ln drive away the donkey of the fatherless; they*ld take the widow’s ox for a pledge.
They*ln thrust the poor off the road; the*ld poor of the earth all hide themselves.
Behold,*ln like wild donkeys in the desert the*ld poor go out to their toil, seeking game; the*ld wasteland yields food for their children.
They*ln gather their fodder in the field, and*ld they glean the vineyard of the wicked man.
They*ln lie all night naked, without clothing, and*ld have no covering in the cold.
They*ln are wet with the rain of the mountains and*ld cling to the rock for lack of shelter.
(There*ln are those who snatch the fatherless child from the breast, and*ld they take a pledge against the poor.)
They*ln go about naked, without clothing; hungry,*ld they carry the sheaves;
among*ln the olive rows of the wicked they make oil; they*ld tread the winepresses, but suffer thirst.
From*ln out of the city the dying groan, and*ld the soul of the wounded cries for help; yet*ld God charges no one with wrong.
“There*pn are those who rebel against the light, who*ld are not acquainted with its ways, and*ld do not stay in its paths.
The*ln murderer rises before it is light, that*ld he may kill the poor and needy, and*ld in the night he is like a thief.
The*ln eye of the adulterer also waits for the twilight, saying,*ld ‘No eye will see me’; and*ld he veils his face.
In*ln the dark they dig through houses; by*ld day they shut themselves up; they*ld do not know the light.
For*ln deep darkness is morning to all of them; for*ld they are friends with the terrors of deep darkness.
“You*pn say, ‘Swift are they on the face of the waters; their*ld portion is cursed in the land; no*ld treader turns toward their vineyards.
Drought*ln and heat snatch away the snow waters; so*ld does Sheol those who have sinned.
The*ln womb forgets them; the*ld worm finds them sweet; they*ln are no longer remembered, so*ld wickedness is broken like a tree.’
“They*pn wrong the barren, childless woman, and*ld do no good to the widow.
Yet*ln God prolongs the life of the mighty by his power; they*ld rise up when they despair of life.
He*ln gives them security, and they are supported, and*ld his eyes are upon their ways.
They*ln are exalted a little while, and then are gone; they*ld are brought low and gathered up like all others; they*ld are cut off like the heads of grain.
If*ln it is not so, who will prove me a liar and*ld show that there is nothing in what I say?”
